Dear Ms. Ramsey:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (517) 899-6024.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Intervention standards and prohibitions
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or pushing a
youth on any part of their body.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth was physically managed by staff and obtained a scratch on
her face.
Investigation On 10/14/24 the agency self-reported Youth A was physically
managed by staff while escalated. Youth A was fighting and
punching at staff. During the physical management, one of the two
staff members may have scratched Youth A in the face. It is
possible Youth A was scratched on accident, but it is unknown.
The scratch is circular and smaller than a dime, but larger than a
pencil eraser. Complainant was contacted via email on 10/16/24;
no additional information was available.
Interviews:
Program Manager was interviewed on-site on 10/16/24 in
coordination with MDHHS Worker. Program Manager reported
that all involved staff are suspended pending investigation. The
restraint video was reviewed by management and found the
restraint technique to be incorrect. The youth was restrained on
the floor, which is not allowed at their facility. In addition, the youth
was restrained in a prone position, which is against licensing
rules. Staff 1 and Staff 2 were identified as being involved in the
restraint. Staff 3, Staff 4 and Staff 5 were witnesses. It was noted
that Staff 5 is a therapist and a trainer for physical management. A
medical exam for Youth A was completed after the incident on
10/8/24. Medical exam noted a scrape on Youth A’s nose.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face on 10/16/24 in collaboration
with MDHHS Worker. Youth A reported being at the facility for
approximately one month. She stated things started out rough, as
she was hurting and attacking people often. Youth A reported
things have improved over the last few weeks. However, there
2

was an incident on 10/8/24. Youth A stated that peers were
making fun of her that day, which caused her to feel unsafe. Youth
A stated she did not tell staff, but she wanted to harm herself.
Youth A went into the bathroom and removed the shower curtain
rod from the wall, then locked herself in a bathroom stall. Youth A
then used the rod to hit herself in the head several times. Staff
were outside of the bathroom at the time and heard the noise.
Staff 4 entered the bathroom and tried to open the bathroom stall.
When Staff 4 was unable to open the stall, Staff 1, Staff 3 and
Staff 5 entered the bathroom to assist. Staff 5 was Youth A’s
therapist and tried talking with her. Staff 1 was able to open the
door and remove the pole from Youth A’s hands. Youth A stated
she believed she was scratched when staff tried to remove the
pole from her hands. Youth A reported she exited the bathroom
and “went after” Staff 3. Youth A was then restrained by staff.
Youth A reported no injuries from the restraint.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 10/16/24 in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth B reported she was
present during the incident on 10/8/24 with Youth A. However, she
did not see what happened in the bathroom with the pole. Youth B
stated she saw Youth A restrained after the bathroom incident.
Youth B was unsure how Youth A obtained a scratch on her nose.
Youth C was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 10/16/24 in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth C reported that she was
present for the incident on 10/8/24, but she did not see what
occurred in the bathroom. Youth C observed that Youth A was
restrained after coming out of the bathroom and attacking staff.
Youth C was unsure of how Youth A received a scratch on her
nose.
Staff 1 was interviewed by phone on 10/23/24 in collaboration
with MDHHS Worker. Staff 1 reported he was present when Youth
A was hitting herself in the bathroom with the shower rod. Staff 1
was also involved in the subsequent restraint. Staff 1 was unsure
how Youth A received a scratch on her nose.
Staff 2 was interviewed by phone on 10/23/24 in collaboration
with MDHHS Worker. Staff 2 stated he witnessed the incident in
the bathroom and participated in physical management with Youth
A. However, Staff 2 was unsure how Youth A received a scratch
on her nose.
Staff 3 was interviewed by phone on 10/23/24 in collaboration
with MDHHS Worker. Staff 3 was a supervisor and reported he
3

was present and observed staff remove the pole from Youth A in
the bathroom. There were no concerns with staff actions. After
leaving the bathroom, Youth A became assaultive and was
restrained. Staff 3 did not observe anyone’s hands near Youth A’s
face. Staff 3 was unsure of how Youth A received a scratch on her
nose.
Staff 4 was interviewed by phone on 10/30/24 in collaboration
with MDHHS Worker. Staff 4 was present when Youth A
barricaded herself in a bathroom stall with a shower curtain rod.
Youth A hit herself in the head with the rod and refused to give it
to staff. Youth A’s therapist (Staff 5) and additional staff were
called to assist. Staff 5 spoke with Youth A through the stall door.
Youth A was attempting to dig the pole into her skin, but staff were
able to get it away from her. Youth A then ran out of the bathroom
and assaulted staff, resulting in a restraint. Staff 4 stated she did
not see how Youth A obtained a scratch on her nose, but believed
it was from hitting herself with the pole. Staff 4 indicated that
Youth A already had the scratch on her nose when she left the
bathroom, prior to being restrained.
Attempts were made to interview Staff 5 on 10/23/24 10/30/24,
11/4/24. However, Staff 5 did not return phone calls and remained
on leave of absence for the duration of the investigation.
Documents Reviewed
• Medical note signed by the physician on 10/8/24 indicate a
scrape on the bridge of Youth A’s nose. Youth A refused to
state where it came from. Scrape was cleaned with alcohol;
bacitracin was applied.
• Incident report dated 10/8/24, authored by Staff 3, did not
indicate any injuries. Information regarding the shower
curtain rod in the bathroom was consistent with information
obtained in interviews.
Analysis No violation was found as there was insufficient information to
indicate the scratch was caused by staff.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Youth restraint; pregnant youth; reduction, prevention; prohibited
Title restraints; elimination of restraints
4

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4159
Section (2) The following restraints are strictly prohibited:
Description (e) Restraining youth in a prone position or any restraint that
restricts the youth's airway.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Staff placed youth in an improper restraint.
Investigation Youth A was interviewed face-to-face on 10/16/24 in collaboration
with MDHHS Worker. Youth A reported she was restrained on
10/8/24, after an incident where she barricaded herself in the
bathroom and used a shower curtain rod as a weapon. Youth A
stated after staff took the shower curtain rod, she became even
more upset when she saw Staff 3 was present. Youth A stated
she did not like Staff 3. Youth A pushed Staff 3, which caused
Staff 1 and Staff 2 to place her in a standing hold in front of Youth
B’s door. Youth B was in her room at the time. Youth A stated the
hold they put her in was incorrect. Staff 3 initiated the first restraint
with Staff 1 and Staff 2 assisting. Youth A stated that staff pulled
her arms up behind her back, twisting her arms, and lifting her up
from the floor. Staff them slammed her down to the ground. Youth
A stated she was not leaning forward or trying to lay down, staff
were pushing her down. Youth A was banging her forehead on the
ground. Another staff put a pillow between her face and the floor.
Youth A tried to use her head to push the pillow away, as she was
having difficulty breathing. Youth A stated this happened in both
restraints that day.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face on 10/16/24 in collaboration
with MDHHS Worker. Youth B reported when Youth A exited the
bathroom, she was punching Staff 2. Then ran up to Staff 3 and
began hitting and kicking him. Youth B then saw Youth A face
down on the ground, with Staff 1 and Staff 2 standing and holding
Youth A’s arms up behind her. Youth B stated that staff are
supposed to let go if a youth goes to the ground. Youth A was
yelling to let her go, but staff kept holding her arms. Eventually
they let Youth A up, and she went after Staff 1. Staff 3 was
laughing and teasing Youth A. Youth A began yelling threats that
she wanted to stab Staff 3, while chasing him around the unit.
Staff 2 and Staff 3 restrained Youth A again. Youth A went face
down to the floor, while staff held her arms up behind her. Youth B
stated that Staff 1 told Youth A to stop hitting if she did not want to
be restrained. Youth B stated she heard Youth A say she could
not breath. Staff were supposed to let her up, as she was face
down on the floor, but they did not. Youth B stated she could not
5

tell if staff pushed her down, or if Youth A dropped her weight to
the ground.
Youth C was interviewed face-to-face on 10/16/24 in collaboration
with MDHHS Worker. Youth C stated she saw staff restrain Youth
A on 10/8/24. Youth C could not recall which staff were involved.
However, Youth C remembered Youth A was attacking staff, when
staff placed her in a restraint. Youth C saw staff holding Youth A’s
arms behind her back, while she was face down toward the floor.
Youth C thought Youth A was pushing her weight to the ground
and did not believe staff were pushing Youth A down. However,
she was watching through her bedroom door and could not be
certain.
Staff 1 was interviewed by phone on 10/23/24 in collaboration
with MDHHS Worker. Staff 1 reported that Staff 2 and Staff 3
assisted with the restraint of Youth A on 10/8/24. Staff 1 indicated
that physical management was used due to Youth A attempting to
harm herself and others. While in the standing hold, Youth A’s
arms were held by Staff 1 and Staff 2. Youth A then pushed her
weight down to the ground, face down. Youth A was yelling,
threatening staff, and kicking. When staff tried to let her go, she
attacked them again. Staff 1 reported he completed CPI training.
Staff 1 stated that CPI training instructs staff to release youth if
they go to the ground. Staff 1 reported they were not corrected or
redirected in the hold. As Staff 3 was a supervisor and did not
request any changes, Staff 1 believed everything was correct.
Staff 2 was interviewed by phone on 10/23/24 in collaboration
with MDHHS Worker. Staff 2 stated he was involved in the
restraint with Youth A on 10/8/24. However, Staff 2 stated that
Youth A was “never officially physically managed. She was held at
different times, but not physically managed”. When asked what
the difference was, Staff 2 stated that physical management would
involve a CPI hold. Staff 2 stated Youth A was never in a CPI
hold, because she was resisting. Staff 2 acknowledged that Youth
A was on the ground, while staff were holding her arms. Staff 2
stated CPI requires staff to release youth when they are on the
ground. Staff 2 stated they would have released Youth A in a
perfect scenario, but this situation was not one. Staff 2 again
stated this was not a CPI hold, as Youth A was laying on the
ground and her arms were held, without pressure. Staff 2 stated
that after Youth A went to the ground, they could not release her,
because she grabbed Staff 1’s leg and would have grabbed
another if her other hand was free. Throughout the hold, staff told
Youth A she could be released once she let go of staff’s leg. Staff
6

2 was informed that any time a youth is held, it is considered a
restraint and CPI must be followed. Staff 2 indicated he was not
informed by any other staff that the hold was incorrect.
Staff 3 was interviewed by phone on 10/23/24 in collaboration
with MDHHS Worker. Staff 3 was a supervisor at the facility. Staff
3 was called to the unit on 10/8/24 to assist with Youth A. Staff 3
recalled that after Youth A exited the bathroom, she tried to punch
Staff 3 and take his keys. Staff 1 and Staff 2 placed Youth A in a
standing hold. Youth A dropped her weight and began hitting her
forehead on the floor. Another staff placed a pillow on the floor to
protect Youth A. Staff continued to hold Youth A’s arms behind
her back, while she was face down on the floor. Staff were not
using pressure, but also could not let go, because Youth A was
aggressive. At one point staff let go and Youth A tried to assault
another staff. Youth A was placed in a hold again and went to the
floor, where she began banging her head again. Staff moved the
pillow under her head. Youth A was yelling, swearing, and making
threats. Staff 3 stated they were not using pressure in the hold,
despite Youth A trying to hit, kick and bite. When Youth A was
released, Staff 3 tried to exit the wing, but Youth A went after him.
Additional staff stood between them and Staff 3 left.
Staff 3 verified that he completed CPI training. When asked why
staff did not let go of Youth A when she was on the floor, Staff 3
stated it was not a restraint. Staff 3 stated that holding a youth’s
wrists is not considered restraint and therefore CPI did not need to
be followed. When asked if he was aware prone restraint was not
allowed, Staff 3 stated it was not a restraint as Youth A put herself
on the ground and they were holding her wrists without pressure
or restricting movement. Staff 3 was informed this was considered
a restraint.
Staff 4 was interviewed by phone on 10/30/24 in collaboration
with MDHHS Worker. Staff 4 reported that Youth A exited the
bathroom and charged at Staff 3. Staff 3 was attempting to leave
the unit, but Youth A kept going after him. Staff 1 and Staff 2
grabbed Youth A’s arms and placed her in a standing hold, bent
over at her waist, with her head bent down to the ground. Youth
A’s feet slid out from under her and she began banging her head
on the floor. Once she began to calm down, staff released her.
However, Youth A began trying to punch staff. Youth A was
placed in the same position with arms behind her, bent at the
torso, facing the floor. Youth A went down to the floor again and
began banging her head on the floor again and staff placed the
pillow under her head again. Staff 4 clarified that staff pushed
7

Youth A down, which upset the youth and caused her to bang her
head. Once she calmed, staff let her go. Youth A went after Staff 3
again. Staff intervened and Staff 3 was able to leave the unit. Staff
4 stated she completed CPI training and believed the holds to be
correct from what she observed and did not hear the Supervisor
(Staff 3), or Therapist (Staff 5) correct anyone. When asked how
staff should respond to a youth on the ground, Staff 4 stated that
staff will release once the youth is calm. Staff 4 was informed that
CPI requires staff to release a youth that has gone down to the
ground.
Attempts were made to interview Staff 5 on 10/23/24 10/30/24,
11/4/24. However, Staff 5 did not return phone calls and remained
on leave of absence for the duration of the investigation.
Video Review
4:46:31PM Staff were in the doorway of the bathroom. The video
did not capture what happened in the bathroom with the shower
curtain rod. At 4:47:07 Youth A and staff exit the bathroom. Youth
A moved her hand toward Staff 2. Staff 2 grabbed Youth A’s wrist
as Staff 1 assisted and placed Youth A in a hold with her arms
raised behind her back and Youth A on her knees. Youth A put
her forehead on the floor and staff released her. This attempted
hold lasted less than ten seconds.
4:47:22 Youth A stood up and began hitting Staff 2. Staff 2 and
Staff 1 grabbed Youth A’s arms and placed her in a CPI Team
Control Position, each holding one wrist, with their other hand on
Youth A’s shoulder blade. Youth A went down to her knees, then
down to the floor, kicking at staff. Youth A began banging her
forehead on the floor. Staff 5 placed a towel under Youth A’s face.
Staff 4 then placed a pillow under Youth A’s face. Indent lines on
the pillow indicated Youth A’s face was pressed into the pillow as
she kicked her legs. It was unclear if this was under her own
power, or due to the hold by staff. Staff 3, Staff 4 and Staff 5
observed until the hold was released after approximately three
minutes.
4:50:27 Youth A stood up and walked toward Staff 3 as he was
walking toward the exit. Due to the camera angle, it was unclear
what Youth A did to Staff 3, however another restraint was
initiated by Staff 2 and Staff 3. Youth A went to the floor, with her
face on the floor again. Staff 4 retrieved the pillow and placed it
near Youth A’s face. The restraint lasted approximately three
minutes.
8

4:53:17 Youth A was released and followed staff into the living
room. Staff 5 held Youth A’s left wrist as she walked. Youth A tried
to pull away from Staff 5 several times, but Staff 5 continued
holding Youth A’s arm. Youth A attempted to get past Staff 1 and
Staff 2, to get to Staff 3. Staff 4 intervened and held Youth A’s left
arm briefly, as the youth tried to push past Staff 1 and Staff 2.
Staff 3 left the unit at 4:54:15. Staff 4 and Staff 5 released Youth
A’s wrist. Youth A paced the unit then sat for a while as Staff 4
and Staff 5 attempted to talk with her. Youth A pulled a curtain
down and put it around her neck. Staff 1 and Staff 5 removed it.
Staff 2 took down the remaining curtains and put them in a locked
area. Youth A followed Staff 1 around the unit. Staff 5 walked
behind Youth A. Youth A picked up an unknown item from the
staff desk, Staff 5 took it out of her hand with the assistance of
Staff 1. Youth A followed Staff 1 around the unit again, then tried
to take the radio from Staff 2. Youth A returned to the staff desk
and was blocked by Staff 2 and Staff 5. Youth A continued trying
to grab something from Staff 2. Staff 2 held Youth A’s hands. Staff
5 stepped in between them, but Youth A continued to try to grab
Staff 2.
4:59:54 Staff 2 placed Youth A’s left arm in a Team Control
Position, with Staff 1 stepping in to take the right arm. Staff 1 and
Staff 2 each held one wrist, with their other hand on Youth A’s
shoulder blades. Youth A went down to her knees. Staff 4 placed
the pillow under Youth A’s head. Youth A went to the ground and
staff released her within a few seconds. The restraint lasted
approximately one minute. Youth A was released and stood,
talking with staff, when video ended.
Documents Reviewed
• Incident Report dated 10/8/24, authored by Staff 3. After
the incident with the shower curtain rod, Youth A exited the
bathroom and became physically aggressive with Staff 2.
Staff 1 and Staff 2 used a “low-level CPI hold”. Youth A
dropped to the floor; staff attempted to release the hold, but
Youth A began hitting her head on the floor. Staff retrieved
a couch pillow and put it under Youth A’s head. Staff
continued to hold Youth A without pressure for
precautionary measures. When staff released Youth A, she
got up from the floor and aggressively walked towards Staff
3 and attempted to punch him. Staff 3 and Staff 2 placed
Youth A in a low-level CPI hold. Youth A dropped to the
floor again and made verbal threats to assault Staff 3, while
kicking and attempting to grab staff. Staff continued the CPI
hold without pressure to prevent staff from being assaulted.
9

Youth A began hitting her head on the floor; staff put a
pillow under her head. Once calm, the CPI hold was
released. Staff 3 left the area due to being the target of the
youth’s aggression.
A note from Program Manager on the incident report
indicated more information was needed in the report.
However, Staff 3 was then placed on leave and ultimately
terminated, unable to amend the report.
• Behavior Management policy:
o (Page 1) The safe use of physical intervention,
including the ability to recognize and respond to
signs of physical distress in clients who are in
physical intervention or who are being placed in
physical intervention.
o (Page 4) Staff are only permitted to utilize approved
behavior management techniques as taught by a
certified Crisis Prevention Institute trainer.
• Crisis Prevention Institute (CPI) training manual for the low-
level Team Control Position indicates: Staff face the same
direction as the youth, maintain close body contact. Staff
keep their inside legs in front of the individual. Staff bring
the youth’s arms across their bodies, securing them to their
hip area. Place the hands closest to the individual’s
shoulders in a C-shape position to direct the shoulders
forward.
• Human Resources files were reviewed. All staff were up to
date on Crisis Prevention Institute training. Three of the five
staff had previous disciplinary action:
o Staff 1 received verbal warnings in February and
August 2024 for attendance. Staff 1 was placed on a
final warning as a result of the 10/8/24 incident.
o Staff 2 received a verbal warning in September 2022
for attendance. Staff 2 was placed on a final warning
as a result of the 10/8/24 incident.
o Staff 3 was previously suspended for violating
agency policy in June 2020. Staff 3 received a final
warning in March 2023 for violating agency policy.
Staff 3 was terminated as a result of the 10/8/24
incident.
Analysis A violation was found due to staff physically managing a youth
outside of the requirements of CPI. In the video, Staff 5 was
observed to pull on Youth A’s arm in an attempt to keep her away
from Staff 3. Staff 1, Staff 2 and Staff 3 were observed to place
Youth A in an incorrect CPI hold, with her arms held high behind
her back, with her body face down on the floor. In two of the four
10

restraints, staff did not release the youth from this hold once she
was in a prone position on the floor. In addition, Staff 4 placed a
pillow under Youth A’s face in an attempt to keep her from
banging her head. Staff 4 did not consider the danger of Youth A
being face down on the floor with a pillow blocking her face.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code Criminal history check, subject to requirements; staff qualifications
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4112
Section (4) A person with ongoing duties shall have both of the following:
Description (a) Ability to perform duties of the position assigned.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Staff failed to intervene and correct staff while observing an
improper restraint.
Investigation Staff 5 has been with the facility since 2008. Staff 5 is a therapist
and trainer for the new behavior management program the agency
started implementing, Safety Care. Staff 5 was certified in Safety
Care on 3/27/24. In addition, Staff 5 was trained in CPI, including
the most recent refresher training on 11/14/23.
Staff 5 observed for approximately seven minutes as Staff 1, Staff
2 and Staff 3 held Youth A in three improper, prone, restraints.
Staff 5 did not intervene to correct or request staff to stop the
improper technique. Staff 5 watched as Staff 4 placed a pillow on
the floor, under Youth A’s face, three times, without intervening.
During interviews with Staff 2 and Staff 3, staff stated they did not
believe the physical management of Youth A was a restraint, as
they did not follow CPI or use pressure. Both staff have been
trained in CPI. Both staff, especially a supervisor (Staff 3), should
have been aware their actions were indeed a restraint.
Analysis A violation was found as Staff 5 is a seasoned, CPI and Safety
Care trained employee, who failed to intervene while a youth was
restrained in an improper and dangerous manner.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was advised that the definition of a restraint needs to
be reviewed with staff, as some staff seemed to need clarification.
11

Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. A corrective action plan is required.
